facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 665 N of 1972 was filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 665 N  of 1972. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal is from judgment and order dated August 27, 1971 of High Court of Judicature at Allahabad in Civil Revision No. 680 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 27, 1971 of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad in Civil Revision No. 680 of 1970.

facts.text: High Court of Allahabad allowed revision of orders passed by Civil Judge, Saharanpur.

anchor.surface_text: is from the order of the High Court of Allahabad allowing on application for revision of orders passed by the Civil Judge, Saharanpur, directing discovery of documents by the respondent

facts.text: High Court dismissed application by respondent for permission to sue forma pauperis.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Judge, Saharanpur, directing discovery of documents by the respondent and dismissing an application by him for permission to sue forma pauperis.

facts.text: Respondent filed suit in forma pauperis on April 29, 1962 against appellant and his wife for recovery of damages of Rs. 7,48,000/- for malicious prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed a suit in forma pauperis on April 29, 1962, against the appellant and his wife for recovery of damages to the tune of Rs. 7,48,000/- for malicious prosecution.

facts.text: Notice of petition to sue in forma pauperis given to State Government and appellant under Order 33 Rule 6 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: Notice of the petition. to sue in forma pauperis was given to the State Government and the appellant under Order 33, Rule 6 of the Civil Procedure Code.

facts.text: Government and appellant filed objections stating respondent is not a pauper.

anchor.surface_text: Both the Government and the appellant filed objections stating that the respondent is number a pauper.

facts.text: Appellant filed application for discovery of documents from respondent to prove not pauper.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter filed an application for discovery of documents from the respondent for proving that the respondent is number a. pauper.

facts.text: Civil Judge on February 23, 1970 ordered respondent to discover on affidavit documents relating to bank accounts (pass books, cheque books, counterfoils etc.) from March 1, 1963 to date of affidavit.

anchor.surface_text: The Court passed an order on February 23, 1970, directing the respondent to discover on affidavit the documents relating to the bank accounts of the respondent, namely, pass books cheque books, companynterfoils, etc., from March 1, 1963, to the date of filing the affidavit of discovery,

facts.text: Order also for documents in respect of properties held by respondent and personal accounts.

anchor.surface_text: as also the documents in respect of the properties held by him and the personal accounts maintained by him.

facts.text: Respondent to file affidavit of discovery on March 8, 1970, no extension allowed.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was to file the affidavit of discovery on March 8, 1970. It was specifically stated that numberextension of time will be allowed for filing the affidavit and that the discovery should be made within the time.

facts.text: Respondent did not file the affidavit in pursuance to the order.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent did number file the affidavit in pursuance to the order.

facts.text: On March 31, 1970, respondent moved application for two months time to file revision against Feb 23 order.

anchor.surface_text: On March 31, 1970, he moved an application stating. that he, wants to file a revision against the order dated February 23, 1970, before the High Court and that two months time may be allowed for the purpose.

facts.text: Court rejected application for time on April 4, 1970, as pauper application pending for seven years.

anchor.surface_text: The Court rejected the application for time on April 4, 1970, on the ground that the application for permission to sue in forma pauperis was pending for the last seven years and that the respondent had ample time for filing the revision if he was diligent in the matter.

facts.text: Respondent's counsel moved another application on April 4, 1970 for adjournment to adduce evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents companynsel then moved another application on the same day stating that the respondent wants to adduce evidence and that since he had number companye to Court in the expectation that his earlier application dated March 31, 1970, for adjournment would be allowed, the case may be adjourned.

facts.text: Court rejected adjournment application.

anchor.surface_text: This application was also rejected by the Court.

facts.text: Court dismissed application for permission to sue in forma pauperis as no evidence of pauperism, directed pay court fee within 15 days.

anchor.surface_text: And as companynsel for the respondent reported numberinstruction and as there was numberevidence to show that the respondent was a pauper, the Court dismissed the application for permission to sue in forma Pauperis and directed the respondent to pay the companyrt fee within 15 days.

facts.text: Respondent filed revision in High Court challenging discovery order of Feb 23, 1970 and dismissal order of April 4, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent challenged the order directing discovery of documents passed on February 23, 1970, and that dismissing his application for permission to sue in forma pauperis passed on April 4, 1970, in revision before the High Court.

facts.text: High Court set aside trial court order for discovery and order dismissing pauper application.

anchor.surface_text: The Court, therefore, set aside the order for discovery as well as the order dismissing the application for permission to sue in forma pauperis.

facts.text: High Court on August 26, 1971 directed respondent to delete name of appellant's wife from array of parties.

anchor.surface_text: This order will number in any way affect the validity of the order passed by the High Court on August 26, 1971, directing the respondent to delete the name of the wife of the appellant from the array of parties.

facts.text: Suit pending for seven years by April 1970.

anchor.surface_text: on the ground that the application for permission to sue in forma pauperis was pending for the last seven years

facts.text: Respondent appeared in person before Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: M. Tarkunde and Hardev Singh, for the appellant. Respondent appeared in person.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Mathew, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Mathew, J.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 27, 1971 of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad in Civil Revision No. 680 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent submitted that the procedure for discovery of documents is number permissible in proceedings under Order 33 and that it is number salutary to adopt the procedure even if permissible. anchor.surface_text: under rules 6 and 7 of Order 33 are summary in character, the sophisticated procedure for discovery should number have been resorted to by the appellant, that the documents of which discovery was sought were number specified in the application of the appellant and, therefore, the application for discovery was bad, that the enquiry under rules 6 and 7 of Order 33 was primarily a matter between respondent and the State Government

issues.text: Whether the enquiry under rules 6 and 7 of Order 33 was primarily a matter between the respondent and the State Government such that trial court should not adopt discovery at instance of private party like appellant

anchor.surface_text: the application for discovery was bad, that the enquiry under rules 6 and 7 of Order 33 was primarily a matter between respondent and the State Government and that the trial companyrt should number have adopted the procedure for discovery and inspection at the instance of a private party like the appellant. The Court further held that the trial Court acted with material irre- gularity as it did number companysider the question of the necessity for discovery of the documents or the relevancy of the documents of which discovery was sought and also for the reason that, in ordering discovery of the documents relating to personal accounts, and pass books, it overlooked the right of the respondent to claim privilege.

issues.text: Whether the trial court acted with material irregularity by not considering necessity, relevancy of documents or overlooking privilege right in ordering discovery

anchor.surface_text: The Court further held that the trial Court acted with material irre- gularity as it did number companysider the question of the necessity for discovery of the documents or the relevancy of the documents of which discovery was sought and also for the reason that, in ordering discovery of the documents relating to personal accounts, and pass books, it overlooked the right of the respondent to claim privilege. And as regards the order passed on April 4, 1970, dismissing the application for permission to sue in forma pauperis after rejecting the application for adjournment, the Court said that the trial Court betrayed an anxiety to get rid of an application to add to the figures of its disposal.

issues.text: Whether the order for discovery was vague

anchor.surface_text: We also do number think that there is any point in the criticism of the High Court that the order for discovery was vague. The first item in the order was in respect of the documents relating to the bank accounts of the respondent from March 1, 1963, to the date of the affidavit. The second item related to documents in respect of the immovable properties held by him during the same period and the third item was in respect of documents relating to the personal accounts maintained by him for the same period.

arguments.claim: Suit commences from moment of application to sue in forma pauperis under Order 33

anchor.surface_text: In Vijay Pratap Singh v. Dukh Haran Nath Singh and another 1 , this Court has held that the suit companymences from the moment an application for permission to sue in forma pauperis as required by Order 33 is presented.

anchor.surface_text: Nor do we think that the High Court was right in holding that the documents ordered to be discovered were number relevant to the injuiry. The documents sought to be discovered need number be admissible in evidence in the enquiry or proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: We venture to think that the High Court was laboring under a mistake when it said that the enquiry into the question whether the respondent was a pauper was exclusively a matter between him and the State Government and that the appellant was number interested in establishing that the respondent was number a pauper.

arguments.claim: High Court jurisdiction under S.115 CPC is limited to jurisdictional error, illegal exercise or material irregularity

anchor.surface_text: The jurisdiction of the High Court under section 115 of the C.P.C. is a limited one. As long ago as 1884, in Rajah Amir Hassan Khan v. Sheo Baksh Singh 1 , the Privy Council made the following observation on s. 622 of the former Code of Civil Procedure,

arguments.claim: Trial court order for discovery not vitiated by jurisdictional error or material irregularity

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court had jurisdiction to pass the order for discovery. Even if lack of jurisdiction is assumed to result from every material error of law--even an error of law within the jurisdiction in the primitive sense of the term-we do number think the order was vitiated by any error of law.

arguments.claim: Refusal to adjourn did not occasion failure of natural justice

anchor.surface_text: We are also number satisfied that the refusal to adjourn occasioned any failure of natural justice so as to render the order a nullity.

arguments.claim: Order for discovery was not vague

anchor.surface_text: We also do number think that there is any point in the criticism of the High Court that the order for discovery was vague. The first item in the order was in respect of the documents relating to the bank accounts of the respondent from March 1, 1963, to the date of the affidavit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suit commences from pauper application per precedent in Vijay Pratap Singh; thus Order 11 r12 applies directly; analogous provisions apply

holdings.text: There is no reason to hold [...] that it is not salutary to resort to the procedure in proceedings under Order 33

anchor.surface_text: There is numberreason to hold, if companyts companyld be saved, that it is number salutary to resort to the procedure in proceedings under Order 33. We think that the High Court was wrong in holding that since the application for discovery did number specify the documents sought to be discovered, the lower Court acted illegally in the exercise of its jurisdiction in ordering discovery.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Policy of saving costs favors discovery in pauper proceedings; rejects respondent's submission

holdings.text: We think that the High Court was wrong in holding that [...] the documents of which discovery was sought were not specified in the application of the appellant

anchor.surface_text: We think that the High Court was wrong in holding that since the application for discovery did number specify the documents sought to be discovered, the lower Court acted illegally in the exercise of its jurisdiction in ordering discovery. Generally speaking, a party is entitled to inspection of all documents which do number themselves companystitute exclusively the other partys evidence of his case or title.

holdings.reasoning_summary: General right to discovery of relevant documents; party cannot specify without knowing what exists

holdings.text: the stage for claiming privilege had not yet been reached. That would be reached only when the affidavit of discovery is made

anchor.surface_text: Order 11, rule 13 provides that every affidavit of documents should specify which of the documents therein set forth the party objects to produce for inspection of the opposite party together with the grounds of objection Nor do we think that the High Court was right in holding that the documents ordered to be discovered were number relevant to the injuiry.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Privilege claimed post-affidavit under O11 r13; no affidavit filed so premature

holdings.text: the documents ordered to be discovered were relevant to the enquiry [...] sufficient if the documents would be relevant for the purpose of throwing light on the matter in controversy

anchor.surface_text: Nor do we think that the High Court was right in holding that the documents ordered to be discovered were number relevant to the injuiry. The documents sought to be discovered need number be admissible in evidence in the enquiry or proceedings. It is sufficient it the documents would be relevant for the purpose of throwing light on the matter in companytroversy.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Documents relevant if throw light on means even if inadmissible; bank accounts etc. relevant to pauperism

holdings.text: the High Court was laboring under a mistake when it said that the enquiry into the question whether the respondent was a pauper was exclusively a matter between him and the State Government

anchor.surface_text: Under Order 33, rule 9, it is open to the Court on the application of the defendant to dispauper the plain-. tiff on the grounds, specified therein, one of them being that his means are such that he ought number to companytinue to sue as a pauper.

holdings.reasoning_summary: O33 r6 notice to opposite party; r9 allows defendant to dispauper; vital interest in avoiding suit without fee

holdings.text: there is any point in the criticism of the High Court that the order for discovery was vague

anchor.surface_text: We also do number think that there is any point in the criticism of the High Court that the order for discovery was vague. The first item in the order was in respect of the documents relating to the bank accounts of the respondent from March 1, 1963, to the date of the affidavit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order specified bank accounts, properties, personal accounts from March 1963 to affidavit date

holdings.text: The trial Court had jurisdiction to pass the order for discovery. [...] the order was vitiated by any error of law

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court had jurisdiction to pass the order for discovery. Even if lack of jurisdiction is assumed to result from every material error of law--even an error of law within the jurisdiction in the primitive sense of the term-we do number think the order was vitiated by any error of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S115 limited to jurisdictional error/illegal exercise/material irregularity per precedents; no such error here

holdings.text: the refusal to adjourn occasioned any failure of natural justice so as to render the order a nullity

anchor.surface_text: We are also number satisfied that the refusal to adjourn occasioned any failure of natural justice so as to render the order a nullity. Nor is there anything to show that in rejecting the application for time the Court acted illegally or with material irregularity in the exercise of its jurisdiction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No failure of natural justice; rejection after 7 years pendency reasonable

holdings.text: We would, therefore, set aside the order of the High Court and allow the appeal

anchor.surface_text: We would, therefore, set aside the order of the High Court and allow the appeal but in the circumstances make numberorder as to companyts. This order will number in any way affect the validity of the order passed by the High Court on August 26, 1971, directing the respondent to delete the name of the wife of the appellant from the array of parties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative holdings justify reversal of High Court orders

precedents.citation: Rajah Amir Hassan Khan v. Sheo Baksh Singh 1

anchor.surface_text: As long ago as 1884, in Rajah Amir Hassan Khan v. Sheo Baksh Singh 1 , the Privy Council made the following observation on s. 622 of the former Code of Civil Procedure, which was replaced by s. 115 of the Code of 1908 The question then is, did the judges of the lower Courts in this case, in the exercise of their jurisdiction, act illegally or with material irregularity.

precedents.case_name: Rajah Amir Hassan Khan v. Sheo Baksh Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: even if lower courts decide wrongly, they do not exercise jurisdiction illegally or with material irregularity if they had jurisdiction
precedents.cited_holding: Whether they decided rightly or wrongly, they had jurisdiction to decide the case and even if they decided wrongly, they did number exercise their jurisdiction illegally or with material irregularity.

anchor.surface_text: In Balakrishna Udayar v. Vasudeva Aiyar 2 , the Board observed It will be observed that the section applies to jurisdiction alone, the irregular exercise or number-exercise of it, or the illegal assumption of it. The section is number directed against companyclusions of law or fact in which the question of jurisdiction is number involved.

precedents.cited_proposition: section 115 applies to jurisdiction alone, irregular or non-exercise or illegal assumption

precedents.citation: N. S. Venkatagiri Ayyangar v. Hindu Religious Endowments Board, Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: In N. S. Venkatagiri Ayyangar v. Hindu Religious Endowments Board, Madras 1 , the Judicial Committee said that section 115 empowers the High Court to satisfy itself on three matters,  a  that the order of the subordinate companyrt is within its jurisdiction  b  that the case is one in which the Court ought to exercise jurisdiction and  c  that in exercising jurisdiction the Court has number acted illegally

precedents.case_name: N. S. Venkatagiri Ayyangar v. Hindu Religious Endowments Board, Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: three matters for High Court under s.115: jurisdiction, ought to exercise, no illegal act or material irregularity

precedents.citation: Manindra Land and Building Corporation Ltd. Bhutnath Banerjee and others 1

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Manindra Land and Building Corporation Ltd. Bhutnath Banerjee and others 1  and Vora Abbashhai Ali-  2 mahomed v. Haji Gulamnabi Haji Safibhai   has held that a distinction must be drawn between the errors companymitted by sub-ordinate companyrts in deciding questions of law which have relation to, or are companycerned with, questions of jurisdiction of the said Court, and errors of law which have numbersuch relation or companynection.

precedents.case_name: Manindra Land and Building Corporation Ltd. v. Bhutnath Banerjee
precedents.cited_proposition: distinction between errors of law related to jurisdiction and those not

precedents.citation: Vora Abbashhai Alimahomed v. Haji Gulamnabi Haji Safibhai 2

anchor.surface_text: and Vora Abbashhai Ali-  2 mahomed v. Haji Gulamnabi Haji Safibhai   has held that a distinction must be drawn between the errors companymitted by sub-ordinate companyrts in deciding questions of law which have relation to, or are companycerned with, questions of jurisdiction of the said Court, and errors of law which have numbersuch relation or companynection. In Pandurang Dhoni Chougute v. Maruti Hari Jadhav 3 , this Court said

precedents.case_name: Vora Abbashhai Alimahomed v. Haji Gulamnabi Haji Safibhai
precedents.cited_proposition: distinction between errors of law related to jurisdiction and those not

precedents.citation: Pandurang Dhoni Chougute v. Maruti Hari Jadhav 3

anchor.surface_text: In Pandurang Dhoni Chougute v. Maruti Hari Jadhav 3 , this Court said The provisions of s. 115 of the Code have been examined by judicial decisions on several occasions. While ex ercising its jurisdiction under S. 115, it is number companypetent to the High Court to companyrect errors of fact however gross they may be, or even errors of law, unless the said errors have relation to the jurisdiction of the Court to try the dispute itself.

precedents.case_name: Pandurang Dhoni Chougute v. Maruti Hari Jadhav
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court under s.115 cannot correct errors of fact or law unless related to jurisdiction; pleas like limitation/res judicata concern jurisdiction

precedents.citation: Anisminic Ltd. v. Foreign Compensation Commission 4

anchor.surface_text: Jurisdiction originally seems to have had the meaning which Lord Reid ascribed to it in Anisminic Ltd. v. Foreign Compensation Commission  4   , namely, the entitlement to enter upon the enquiry in question. If there was an entitlement to enter upon an enquiry into the question, ben any subsequent error companyld only be regarded as an error within the jurisdiction.

precedents.case_name: Anisminic Ltd. v. Foreign Compensation Commission
precedents.cited_proposition: entitlement to enter upon the enquiry; errors within jurisdiction unless jurisdictional defects like bad faith, natural justice breach etc.

anchor.surface_text: The best known formulation of this theory is that made by Lord Denean in R. v. Bolton 1 . He said that the question of jurisdiction is determinable at the companymencement, number at the companyclusion of the enquiry. In Anisminic Ltd.  2  , Lord Reid said But there are many cases where, although the tribunal had jurisdiction to enter on the enquiry it has done or failed to do something in the companyrse of the enquiry which is of such a nature that its decision is a nullity.

precedents.cited_proposition: question of jurisdiction determinable at commencement, not conclusion

anchor.surface_text: In Anisminic Ltd.  2  , Lord Reid said But there are many cases where, although the tribunal had jurisdiction to enter on the enquiry it has done or failed to do something in the companyrse of the enquiry which is of such a nature that its decision is a nullity. It may have given its decision in bad faith. It may have made a decision which it had numberpower to make.

precedents.case_name: Anisminic Ltd. v. Foreign Compensation Commission
precedents.cited_proposition: cases where tribunal had jurisdiction to enter but decision nullity due to errors like bad faith, misconstruing provisions, natural justice etc.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the High Court was wrong in holding that since the application for discovery did number specify the documents sought to be discovered, the lower Court acted illegally in the exercise of its jurisdiction in ordering discovery. Generally speaking, a party is entitled to inspection of all documents which do number themselves companystitute exclusively the other partys evidence of his case or title.
We would, therefore, set aside the order of the High Court and allow the appeal but in the circumstances make numberorder as to companyts.

anchor.surface_text: Nor do we think that the High Court was right in holding that the documents ordered to be discovered were number relevant to the injuiry. anchor.surface_text: We also do number think that there is any point in the criticism of the High Court that the order for discovery was vague. The first item in the order was in respect of the documents relating to the bank accounts of the respondent from March 1, 1963, to the date of the affidavit.
We would, therefore, set aside the order of the High Court and allow the appeal but in the circumstances make numberorder as to companyts.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court had jurisdiction to pass the order for discovery. Even if lack of jurisdiction is assumed to result from every material error of law--even an error of law within the jurisdiction in the primitive sense of the term-we do number think the order was vitiated by any error of law.
We would, therefore, set aside the order of the High Court and allow the appeal but in the circumstances make numberorder as to companyts.

We would, therefore, set aside the order of the High Court and allow the appeal but in the circumstances make numberorder as to companyts.
